liable when seen very obliquely.
It must be obvious to the most superficial observer 
that the same perspective form which correctly represents 
a certain pair of eyes in one position of the face, can-
-not be an exact representation of the <u>same <\u> eyes in 
another; but in cases of such slight obliquity as is 
usually given to the eyes in a portrait that is intend-
ed to look at the spectator, the variations of the form
<s>of the lids form <\s> of the lids from obliquity is less than the
difference observable in the eyes of different persons. Hence 
it is that a pair of eyes drawn looking at us will 
best admit of being warped from their intended direction 
by application of a new position of the other features of the face.
The converse of this experiment may also be made 
with success within the same limitted extent. Eyes
